executive_summary: Over the past five years, the Pizza Restaurant Franchises industry has experienced steady growth attributable to increasing consumer sentiment and consumer spending. Consumer spending has improved, resulting in increased expenditure on food away from home, including at pizza franchises. The industry has even grown faster than the broader Pizza Restaurants industry as the number of establishments operated under a franchise agreement has grown substantially. Many pizza franchisors have sold their company-owned locations to franchisees, expanding the number of franchised locations. However, like the broader Pizza Restaurants industry, pizza franchises have experienced increased competition from other pizza restaurants and the broader food service sector. In 2020, industry revenue benefited from the work-from-home arrangements stemming from the COVID-19 pandemic. Nonetheless, pizza franchises were required to operate with delivery and take-out services only. As a result, industry revenue has increased an annualized 2.3% to $45.0 billion over the past five years, including 0.7% growth in 2023 alone. Nonetheless, profit has decreased over the past five years due to increased pricing competition and rising input costs.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: When consumers feel more confident about their economic situation, they are more likely to eat at a pizza restaurant instead of staying home and focusing on saving money.
Rising health consciousness directly affects food choices as consumers become more concerned about their diet.

international_trade_points.trade_description: The Pizza Restaurant Franchises industry operates as part of the broader food-services industries serving the domestic market.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region is home to the largest share of industry establishments, primarily stemming from the large population in this region.
The Mid-Atlantic region is also dense with pizza restaurant franchises, home to major US cities like New York City, Philadelphia and Washington DC.
The Great Lakes region also holds a significant portion of the industry's establishments, with states like Ohio and Illinois favoring pizza.
The West region accounts for a disproportionately small share of industry establishments due to diverse tastes and focus on healthy eating.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Regulated by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), the Model Food Code is a best-practice guide to food handling and presentation. This regulation applies to all pizza restaurants and is updated yearly.
Also regulated by the FDA, pizza restaurants must follow guidelines regarding nutritional values for individual foods and meals.
Most employees at pizza restaurants are part-time and considered low-skill workers (i.e., little training or formal education is required).

basis_points.basis_description: Price is one of the most important competitive factors in the industry. Consumers that turn to industry establishments are typically price sensitive since some consider eating away from home a luxury expense.
Pizza restaurants also compete based on location.
Product offerings and menu items are essential for pizza restaurants.
